description: From Middle French predicat (French prédicat), from post-classical Late Latin praedicātum (“thing said of a subject”), a noun use of the neuter past participle of praedicō (“I proclaim”), as Etymology 2, below.

adjectives.description: predicate (comparative more predicate, superlative most predicate)

entries.meaning: (grammar) Of or related to the predicate of a sentence or clause.
(law) Relating to or being any of a series of criminal acts upon which prosecution for racketeering may be predicated.
(grammar) The part of the sentence (or clause) which states a property that a subject has or is characterized by.

(logic) A term of a statement, where the statement may be true or false depending on whether the thing referred to by the values of the statement's variables has the property signified by that (predicative) term.
examples: A propositional variable may be treated as a nullary predicate.
A predicate is either valid, satisfiable, or unsatisfiable.

entries.meaning: (computing) An operator or function that returns either true or false.

description: From Latin praedicātus, perfect passive participle of praedicō (“publish, declare, proclaim”), from prae + dicō (“proclaim, dedicate”), related to dīcō (“say, tell”). Doublet of preach.

verbs.description: predicate (third-person singular simple present predicates, present participle predicating, simple past and past participle predicated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To announce, assert, or proclaim publicly.
(transitive) To assume or suppose; to infer.
(transitive, originally US) to base (on); to assert on the grounds of.
examples: The law is what constitutes both desire and the lack on which it is predicated.

entries.meaning: (transitive, grammar) To make a term (or expression) the predicate of a statement.
(transitive, logic) To assert or state as an attribute or quality of something.
examples: This quality becomes real as a mental concept when it is predicated of all the objects possessing it (“quod de pluribus natum est praedicari”).
